data.text: Appendix A - NHSLA minimum data set
Appendix B - Training Grid to Satisfy Trust & NHSLA
Appendix C - Mandatory Three-Day Training Programme for Maternity Services,
Multidisciplinary to include, Medical Staff, Anaesthetists (Drills and Skills only) Midwives and Maternity Care Assistants
Appendix E - Return from Leave (prolonged absence checklist)
Appendix F - Bank and Agency Only Midwives induction checklist
Appendix G - Bank only midwives' mandatory requirements to work within maternity
Appendix H - Midwives and MCA Rotation Competency Checklist
To provide clear guidance, enabling all staff to be aware of what mandatory training they should undergo. This is based as a minimum on the NHSLA minimum data set.

To fulfil the Trust's responsibility in ensuring that all members of the organisation are valued by attending mandatory training. Mandatory training provision should be part of the individual's working hours.
To set out the duties and responsibilities of the service to ensure staff attend mandatory training commensurate to their role

Core risk management training for staff has been identified to meet legislative and statutory requirements as well as Health and Patient Safety standards such as those defined by the NHS Litigation Authority and Care Quality Commission.
To set down the ideal standard for mandatory training monitoring
To provide a way for designated managers to schedule and track staff progress with mandatory training
Mid Essex Hospitals Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of the individuals.

Women's and Children's Division, in line with the generic Trust policy is committed to ensuring that all staff working within Maternity Services have the opportunity to attend the mandatory training programme to ensure they work effectively in their roles.

It recognises its legal and ethical responsibilities to create and maintain a working environment, which will ensure the welfare and health and safety of its employees, women, babies and families, who use our services.
Mandatory training takes place on the Maternity site. Attendance is both recorded and entered on both Trust and Maternity Databases.
This policy applies to all staff working in Maternity Services at Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust.

The policy includes statements that relate to people who have disabilities or language difficulties and HR, Learning and Development, and Managers will address these needs as necessary, and wherever possible make reasonable adjustments to accommodate the need.
Mandatory Training is defined as any training episode that has been agreed by the organisation as essential to the safe practice of an individual in the workplace (DOH).
All staff who have a permanent contract (full/part time, fixed term or Bank).
All Staff with direct patient contact.
Duties for the Provision of the Training Needs Analysis (TNA)
Duties are divided between the Practice Development Midwife (PDM), Risk Management Midwife, and Head of Midwifery (HoM)

The level of attendance at the mandatory 3-day training is set at 85% The PDM, Risk Management Midwife and HoM should review staff attendance 6 monthly and develop an action plan to address identified shortfalls in attendance.
For all other mandatory training, the attendance is for all relevant staff groups. Attendance will be on an allocation basis.
Managerial Responsibility in Identifying Mandatory Requirements for Staff
Line Managers must work through the TNA grid attached with their staff members, identify and agree a mandatory training schedule to be completed for staff members.

Based on headcount for the Maternity Services, managers must calculate the numbers of hours of mandatory training provision that is required for each member of staff. Training commences from January. This will enable planning for a suitable training schedule.

Maternity Services must present the training template when required with uptake compliance against the training plan at the Maternity Services Risk Management meeting for discussion and appropriate corrective action to address any problems arising.
The Role of the Training Administration Team
Maternity secretaries will take bookings and maintain records. Staff will be emailed a week prior to training with a programme for information.

Cancellations will be accepted up to 24 hours prior to the date of session delivery. ‘Did not attends' (DNA) are those who do not arrive on the day or cancelled within 24 hours of the commencement of the course.
For mandatory 3-day training, maternity staff will be either rostered to attend or self-roster allocated by the maternity secretaries on extension 3004
For mandatory 3-day training, medics will be rostered to attend.
For 6 monthly CTG update, midwives will be informed 1 month in advance as a reminder, in the event of non-compliance, a follow up letter will be sent and their named line-manager will be informed.
Staff attendance will be entered onto the local database by the maternity secretary. The PDM will send attendance to training and development for entry onto the Trust database.

Managers will be notified of non-attendance within one week of training event in order for corrective actions and further bookings to be arranged. The Clinical Director will be notified of medic non-attendance.
Areas of concern with staff who DNA 3 times will be escalated to Line Management for corrective action to be taken.
For 6 monthly CTG update, the midwife's named line-manager will be informed.
Review of Mandatory Training Provision and TNA

10.1.1 The Training Needs Analysis is formally reviewed annually to ensure it meets all legislative and regulatory requirements. This review is undertaken by the Practice Development Midwife (PDM) with the Trust Mandatory Training Manager, Risk Management Midwife, Professional Midwifery Advocates, Named Midwife Safeguarding and Clinical Practices Group (CPG). The annual TNA will then be formally approved by the Multidisciplinary Risk Management Group.
10.1.2 The CPG is drawn from practitioners within the service, Anglia Ruskin University and Lay Representation. The terms of reference for the group are covered in Appendix C

10.1.3 Training information is available from the PDM, Maternity Secretaries and circulated on email. It will also be posted on the Intranet for information on the Maternity webpage. (Refer to Appendix D)
Ongoing Review of the TNA and Attendance at Training by Multidisciplinary Risk Management Group
10.2.1 The multidisciplinary risk management group with the responsibility for risk locally within maternity will monitor and discuss mandatory training attendance as a minimum of 6
monthly. Where concerns relating to attendance are identified, the group should make
10.2.2 The Multidisciplinary Risk Management Group review learning from incidents, complaints and claims and other sources in accordance with the Maternity Risk Management Strategy and Policy.
10.2.3 In addition, the Directorate Audit Lead will submit key learning from clinical audit activity on an ad hoc basis.

10.2.4 Where review of learning from audits, incidents, complaints and claims identifies training deficiencies, the Lead Midwife for Clinical Governance will develop and implement changes to the TNA with the Practice Development Midwife (PDM).

All midwifery and obstetric staff must attend yearly mandatory training which includes skills and drills training, including both basic adult and maternal life support update. There is a multi-disciplinary approach to the delivery and participation of training. Immediate life support training is also available in the Trust.
In addition, multi-disciplinary live drills to be conducted in clinical areas bi-annually and attendance registered.
All midwifery and obstetric staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are up-to-date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
Anaesthetists must attend annually obstetric skills and drills training. This can be accessed through maternity mandatory training or live drills.

All midwives must complete a return from leave form on return to work from either long- term sickness or maternity leave. This form is to address their individual learning needs and areas of consolidation on return to work. A copy of this should be kept in the midwives personal file and be signed by their line manager. (Refer to Appendix F)

All agency and bank only midwives must complete a midwives' induction checklist on joining the trust (Refer to Appendix G). New bank only midwives must also complete an orientation programme and mandatory Proforma before being able to work on the wards independently. A copy of the Bank Midwives Proforma must be sent to the bank office and an additional copy returned to the practice development midwife (Refer to Appendix H)

All locum doctors must complete the ‘Essential Information for Locum/Agency/Bank Staff' document which provides a brief induction to help orientate the locum doctor to the Trust. Patient safety is a priority at MEHT and thus the Patient Safety Charter should also be read. (Refer to Appendix J)

It is the locum doctor's responsibility to complete the ‘Essential Information for Locum/Agency/Bank Staff' document. The document should be used at the beginning of the first shift only on a ward/department. The document must be returned to Medical Resources/ Clinical Operations Centre at the end of the shift.

All Midwives on rotation to update their skills must complete a rotation competency checklist with the aim to consolidate areas for development in each new rotation and address their learning needs (Refer to Appendix I). If additional support or the rotation does not address their learning needs please refer to their line manager as soon as possible

Maternity Care Assistants - all maternity care assistants on induction to the Trust will attend a core skills training session with the Practice Development Team within maternity before working on the wards. At the induction session, MCA's will receive an induction pack and skills passport to complete and use as a tool for further development. (Refer to Appendix E)

All maternity care assistants will be issued with a maternity passport to guide their professional development and give guidance to ensure all staff are working within their sphere of practice. The passport consists of a traffic light code, highlighting skills they can perform within MEHT Maternity Services, skills they can perform once further education has been completed and skills maternity care assistance cannot perform. The Skills passport can contribute to their yearly appraisal and is encouraged to be used as a base for their personal development portfolio. (Refer to Appendix E)

All new Maternity Care Assistants' (Bank only) will need to complete an orientation programme and complete both the Skills passport (Refer to Appendix D) and Bank MCA proforma before being able to work on the wards independently. A copy of the Bank MCA proforma must be sent to the Bank office and an additional copy returned to the Practice Development Midwife (Refer to Appendix E)

All Maternity Care Assistants on rotation to update their skills must complete a rotation competency checklist with the aim to consolidate areas for development in each new rotation and address their learning needs (Refer to Appendix I). If additional support or the rotation does not address their learning needs please refer to their line manager as soon as possible
Professional Midwifery Advocates provide a mechanism of support and guidance to women and midwives. Professional Midwifery Advocates are experienced practising midwives who
have undertaken further education in order to supervise midwifery services and to advise and support midwives and women in their care choices.

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy (register number 08076), the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Maternity annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.
As a minimum the following specific requirements will be monitored:
A completed training needs analysis (TNA), which as a minimum must include the list of topics in the TNA Minimum Data Set
Process for checking that all staff attend and complete the relevant training programmes in accordance with the training needs analysis
Process for following up those who fail to attend and complete relevant training programmes
System for coordinating records of training and archiving

System for ensuring that the results of audits, learning from incidents, complaints and claims and other information sources, are considered as part of the ongoing review of training by the overarching committee with responsibility for risk locally
How the maternity service intends to achieve a multidisciplinary approach to training, including emergency drills
System for regular review of attendance at skills and drills training, by the overarching committee with responsibility for risk locally, as a minimum six monthlies

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Multi-disciplinary Risk Management Group (MRMG) and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance Meeting (DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Clinical Governance Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.

As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability  to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.

Quarterly memos are sent to line managers to disseminate to their staff the most currently approved guidelines available via the intranet and clinical guideline folders, located in each designated clinical area.

Guideline monitors have been nominated to each clinical area to ensure a system whereby obsolete guidelines are archived and newly approved guidelines are now downloaded from the intranet and filed appropriately in the guideline folders. ‘Spot checks' are performed on all clinical guidelines quarterly.

Quarterly Clinical Practices group meetings are held to discuss ‘guidelines'. During this meeting, the practice development midwife can highlight any areas for future training needs which can be met using methods such as ‘workshops' or to be included in future ‘skills and drills' mandatory training sessions.

A quarterly ‘maternity newsletter' is issued to all staff with embedded icons to highlight key changes in clinical practice to include a list of newly approved guidelines for staff to acknowledge and familiarise themselves with and practice accordingly. Midwives that are on maternity leave or ‘bank' staff have letters sent to their home address to update them on current clinical changes.
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's Staff Focus that is sent via email to all staff.
Approved guidelines will be disseminated to appropriate staff quarterly via email.

Regular memos are posted on the guideline and audit notice boards in each clinical area to notify staff of the latest revised guidelines and how to access guidelines via the intranet or clinical guideline folders.
Clinical Negligence Scheme for Trusts (2012) Maternity, Clinical Risk Management Standards Version 1 2012/13 NHS Litigation Authority January.
Royal College of Anaesthetists. (2009). Guidelines for the provision of Anaesthetic Services' (GPAS). Chapter 10. Obstetric Services. London: RCOA.
King's Fund. (2008). Safe Births: Everybody's Business - Independent Inquiry into the Safety of Maternity Services in England. London: King's Fund. Available at: www.kingsfund.org.uk

Royal College of Anaesthetists, Royal College of Midwives, Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health. (2007). Safer Childbirth: Minimum Standards for The Organisation and Delivery of Care in Labour. London: RCOG Press. Available at: www.rcog.org.uk
Maternity Care Working Party. (2006). Modernising Maternity Care - A Commissioning Toolkit for England (2nd Edition). London: The National Childbirth Trust, The Royal College
of Midwives, The Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists. Available at: www.rcog.org.uk
Minimum Data Set as outlined by NHSLA

Within the NHSLA Risk Management Standards there are key subject areas in relation to risk which incorporate aspects of training. The organisation must therefore ensure it considers the following areas of risk management training for inclusion on the training needs analysis at 1.1.9
As a minimum, the following should be considered: Standard 1
Early recognition of severely ill pregnant women
Assessment & management of all types of perineal trauma
Mental Health Training – to include as a minimum: maternal mental health disorders, risk assessment methods and referral route
Full Physical Examination of The Newborn
Care of women following operative interventions *
* It is not intended that this training includes staff who are employed in a recovery role
Training Grid to Satisfy Trust & NHSLA

table_items.text: MINIMUM Data Set as outlined by NHSLA
Early recognition of severely ill pregnant women
Assessment & Management of all types of perineal trauma
Mental Health Training - to include as a minimum: maternal mental health disorders, risk assessment methods and referral route
Full Physical Examination of the Newborn
Care of women following operative interventions (it is not intended that this training includes staff who are employed in a recovery role)
Domestic Violence, Forced Marriage, Female Genital, Mutilation
Staff with specialist roles in safeguarding

data.text: Once face to face & then annual update
One-off with bi- annual updates or as required
One-off, then entered onto mentor register
Maternity Care Assistant Induction pack and Skills Passport
Welcome to Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust.  We hope you enjoy working here and that you can develop your professional career with us, to our mutual advantage.

This induction pack is a helpful guide to your new work place and a key tool in learning basic information as well useful contacts to make your induction a smooth and informed journey. As well as a pack to help the first few weeks, there is a passport section that has been based upon a ‘traffic light system' (refer to page 2 for details), highlighting key core skills and competencies we would expect you to achieve in green.

We call it a passport as we believe and value personal staff development and feel as you travel through your career with us you can use your passport as a way of documenting your clinical achievements. It also allows you to be aware of your role as a Maternity Care assistant (MCA) and the limitations within this role.

We advise completion of the green skills (refer to page 2 for details) within six-months of you commencing a substantive employment contract with us. These cover the core skills an MCA should be competent in. It is acknowledged that staff working in specified areas will not complete all the listed competencies; however support through the practice development team and rotation will allow for your skills to develop.
Bank only staff are expected to maintain their passports as evidence of their competence and should aim to complete the green skills within 12 months, dependant on shifts worked within maternity.
We strive to continue your personal development plan with a yearly Trust Knowledge Service Framework reviews (KSF) and three protected study days to maintain core skills
Any feedback on this induction handbook would be useful and could help us to improve future handbooks

An MCA is a Support Worker who plays a vital role in supporting midwives to deliver quality care to babies, mothers and their partners. The Royal College of Midwives (RCM) recognises that support workers perform tasks holistically, working as part of a team and requires a wide range of competences  including:  communication  skills,  problem  solving,  recognising  and  responding appropriately to emergency situations. An MCA will assist with the maintenance of a safe care environment  including  cleaning,  preparing,  checking  equipment  and  stocking  rooms  with  a particular  reference  to  infection  prevention  and  maintaining  a  safe  working  environment  for patients, visitors and staff. Under guidance from qualified staff, sensitive and appropriate clinical care is delivered to meet individuals' needs, respecting personal dignity and beliefs. In addition, MCA's  should  ensure  all  information  is  handled  and  exchanged  with  care,  accuracy  and sensitivity, maintaining patient confidentiality at all times.
Red Skills: Not to be undertaken by the maternity care assistant
Amber Skills: That will require further training
Green Skills: Core skills an MCA just require
Maternity Care Assistants must work within their sphere of responsibility and all clinical skills should be delegated and then reported back to a qualified member of the multidisciplary team.
The registered practitioner is accountable for delegating the task and the maternity care assistant is accountable for accepting and performing the delegated task.
Your passport is your way of providing evidence of your competence and it is your responsibility to ensure completion

There are two buzzers widely used within maternity one being a general “patient call buzzer” and a louder continuous “emergency buzzer”. Familiarise yourself with these and also the electronic wall mounted panel which indicated what area and bed the buzzer is coming from. It is all MCA's responsibility to answer both buzzers and act appropriately within completing this task.
1.1.2 How to use the trust pager system

It is an important tool for all MCA's to be able to use our pager system when delegated to do so. If possible, stay near the phone until the person has returned your call but please take into consideration that although it only takes less than a minute to activate, the recipient will need to be available and have access to a phone.

If the recipient is expected to call back to another extension, please ensure that there is someone available to answer the call. If called into a room to assist and the task is delegated to page another member of staff please use phones and resources provided in the room if available.
Dial #6555- you will then hear “welcome to the multitone paging system” as soon as you hear “welcome” you can enter the required pager number
You will then hear “thank you please enter 4 digit message” this is your receiving contact number for the call to be returned to.
Your message will then be processed and you can hang up and await message

In emergencies an MCA might be asked to put one of two rapid emergency calls out this is completed by dialing ‘4444' from any phone. This will go straight to switch whom will instantly call all appropriate people according to the code you give.
The two codes we use are:
Code Blue – This is related to the baby
Code Red – This is related to the mother
With each call give the code and location of the incident.
Staff may only park in the designated staff parking areas by displaying a valid parking permit. To obtain or renew your permit contact the car parking office on ext 6115.

This can be given at the discretion of your line manager, either in person or over the telephone, and will be dealt with on an individual basis so that a sympathetic, appropriate response is achieved.

Please read the trust sickness policy found on every ward area and on the trust intranet. Sickness should be reported directly to the beelpholder within working hours 08:00-16:00 hours after this time the co-ordinator/senior midwife in charge should be informed. On return to work complete a return to work form and interview with your line manager or co-ordinator on duty.
You will be given a NHS Care identity Service card which is password protected to enable you access to our paper light system once you've have been trained.
There is a strict infection prevention policy across the Trust. A copy of the policy is available on the Trust Intranet

Computers are available for staff to use in all clinical areas. To gain access contact IT after sending your IT form after Trust induction. Email accounts can be accessed on any computer (yahoo and hotmail accounts excluded). It is to your benefit that you obtain e-mail access as soon as possible as most information is disseminated in this way, such as newsletters, new guidelines etc. You will need to contact the IT Department to set up your account on

Notice boards are located in all areas of the Directorate. You should check them regularly for details of forthcoming training events, important information/updates, guidelines, risk management information.
For an appointment, contact extension 4089. You can be referred by your line manager or alternatively self refer.

For midwifery staff based at Broomfield, post is delivered to the post boxes situated in the staff room on Labour Ward. If you are based in the midwife led birthing units or community office post will be delivered directly to each area.

In line with national standards, the units are covered by a CCTV system. All staff are issued with a photo ID swipe card which MUST be worn at ALL times. A copy of all security guidelines are kept on each ward. There are lockers available in the clinical areas for use while on duty. It is advisable not to bring unnecessary valuables on to the site.

Appropriate behaviour is required at all times in line with Trust guidelines. Rudeness is always unacceptable and a caring supportive atmosphere between staff is essential. We have a strict uniform policy at this Trust and a copy of this can be found in every clinical area and also on the Trust intranet. Please note theatre blues should only be worn in theatre and on Labour Ward
No mobile phones or any other personal electronic items are permitted on the clinical area unless during your designated break.

The Warner library is staffed by a full time librarian, and is situated to the rear end of the Medical Academic Unit. There is an up to date collection of textbooks and monographs and we are subscribed to 100 journals.

Maternity Care Assistants are required to attend the two mandatory training sessions and a core skill study day every year to ensure ongoing personal development and knowledge. To book upon these study days please contact the Maternity secretaries on extension 3004.
Please contact Susie Denhart, Practice Development Midwife (PDM) for further information and training needs.

Salaries are paid directly into your bank account on the th of each month. If this date falls on a weekend or bank holiday then salaries are paid the previous Friday. Any queries about your pay should be directed to the Payroll Department. Pay slips are collected from the cashiers' office and delivered to your ward.
Bank will be paid weekly on Fridays, based on submission of your time sheet by Thursday each week

Your off duty will be published approximately six to eight weeks in advance. Our off duty is published via Mapps and can be accessed on any hospital computer. Requests must be made well in advance using Mapps. All new starters can access Mapps and must contact Mapps support on 4774 for assistance.
All bank availability will be fairly distributed no not self-roster as your shift will not be guaranteed. All bank must go through Duncan Fraser and be put on by the team leader/bleepholder.
Shift Patterns Substantive Shift Patterns Bank Only

All staff members are rotational which requires skills to be maintained to work in any Mid Essex hospitals maternity facilities. These include the Antenatal Clinic, Community, Day Assessment Unit (DAU), Labour Ward, Co-located Unit, Birthing Units located at St Peters, Maldon and WJC, Braintree and the Postnatal Ward.

If you're doing a bank shift it may also be required to move from your original planned place of work dependant of the needs of the service. If not competent in an area please alert the bleep holder/labour ward co ordinator.

It is important to remember that learning takes place using a variety of methods and everyone learns  at  a  different  pace.  You  may  find  reading  helps  you  to  learn,  while  others  will  find observation better. Once you are ready, you will be able to perform the task under the supervision of a midwife; there should then be a discussion between yourself and the midwife about your performance. It is only then that the midwife can assess you as competent and you can perform the task unsupervised.

Please note that some of these skills you may already have achieved in previous experience, therefore following a discussion with the PDM and evidence of competence documented you can then have these signed off.
Competence brings together knowledge, skills and attitudes and will result in you having the skills and ability to practice safely and effectively without the need for direct supervision.

We encourage each member of our MCA team to develop their own personal portfolio this will include this passport and any evidence of courses and mandatory training completed. By having a personal portfolio you can have your achievements and learning opportunities logged which will enhance your career development and provide you with your evidence of learning.
Antepartum= The period from conception to labour (Antenatal period)
Amniotic Fluid= The fluid that surrounds a developing baby

APH= Antepartum haemorrhage this is bleeding from the vagina before labour starts Apgar scoring system= A method of evaluating a baby's health immediately after birth. ARM = artificial rupture of membranes
BMI =Body Mass index. This is the weight in kg divided by the square of the height in meters. BO= Bowels open
Brady = bradycardia a slowing of the fetal heart rate
CTG= Cardiotocograph/or electronic fetal monitoring of the baby's heart. Cx= Cervix
Dopplar = machine to listen to the baby's heart
FSE= fetal scalp electrode (attachment to baby's head to monitor the fetal heart)
Fundus = the top of your uterus, used when estimating the size of the uterus
IM= intramuscular – one way of giving an injection
IOL= induction of labour (artificially starting labour)
IV=intravenous- a way of giving medication or extra fluids into a being in your arm or hand Lie= describes the position of the baby's spine in relation to the maternal spine
Lochia= vaginal loss of blood afterbirth
Para= number of babies from previous pregnancies born after 24 weeks
PN= postnatal- after the baby is born (Also known as postpartum)
Mec = Meconium- babies first bowel movement it is dark and sticky
MEOWS = Maternity early observation warning score
SBR= serum bilirubin- a blood test for jaundice
STP = St Peters Hospital (Stand alone maternity unit in Maldon)
WJC= William Julien Courtauld Hospital (stand alone maternity unit in Braintree)

Bernadette O'Sullivan Team Leader DAU Bernadette.osullivan@meht.nhs.uk
Maternity Bleep Holder ( 08:00- 16:00) All sickness to be reported through this bleep during working hours
Labour Ward Co- Ordinator Bleep: All sickness to be reported through this bleep from 16:00- 08:00

data.text: Compliance with local and national policies and guidelines

table_items.text: Signature of assessor / self- assessment if evidence demonstrated

Adult resuscitation (Annual) Support the midwife with neonatal resuscitation (Annual) Attend and be involved in skills and drills training (Annual) Moving and handling (Bi-Annual) Equipment training (Once- self assessment and as new equipment is introduced to the unit) Infection prevention (Annual) Blood competencies (Every 3 year complete work booklets- Once taking blood)
Signature of assessor / self- assessment if evidence demonstrated

Make and receive telephone calls with awareness of the Trust Confidentiality Policy Communicating key information to colleagues Aware of own responsibilities to respect and maintain confidentiality Contact appropriate staff using bleep/page and emergency systems Documentation policy read and demonstrated Use the security system/intercom Gain access to the IT system and email. Check email regularly as way of receiving updates ( you can also gain access from home) Aware of own responsibilities to respect and maintain confidentiality Obtain and read the information governance handbook
Signature of assessor / self- assessment if evidence demonstrated

Comply with legal requirements for patient/ client confidentiality Read, understood and adhere to the dress code As per job description prepare and undertake agreed clinical procedures/practices and observations Awareness that MCA's can obtain union representation via the Royal College of Midwives (RCM). This included opportunities to receive regular evidence based information.
Health and Safety and Fire Safety
Signature of assessor / self- assessment if evidence demonstrated

Fire Safety Policy Location of Fire extinguishers/ emergency exits and who your fire marshals are Fire drill session (mandatory training) Personal Occupation health requirements up to date and maintained Health and Safety policy Awareness of the Control of substances hazardous to health policy(COSHH)
Signature of assessor / self- assessment if evidence demonstrated

Recognises vulnerable patients and reports concerns about welfare issues to the midwife in charge Level 1- At Trust induction Level 2 – Face to face 2 hour session or on NHS E-Learning ( For details contact PDM) Level 3- Whole day training. Please note this needs to be completed every 3 years to ensure competence
Signature of assessor / self- assessment if evidence demonstrated

Read and understands the infection control policy Demonstrates (PPE) Personal Protective Equipment and hand hygiene constantly throughout the day. Gloves, Apron with any procedure Standard hand washing technique Read and understands the needle stick policy Understand rational of the Datix Web and can complete one

data.text: Skills Expected by  Maternity Care Assistants

table_items.text: Observed skill & signature, print and date of person you observed
Demonstrated Competence and evidence of education provided.

Cleaning and making beds Cleaning of rooms and equipment Restocking equipment in clinical area other than midwives delivery trolley Prepare clinical area/rooms depending on needs (locating equipment) Reporting faulty equipment Management of spillages such as blood and other body fluids Dispatch laboratory specimens using correct procedures and document Obtain test results using computer system for midwife/doctor review Assist with cleaning and checking adult resuscitaire and resuscitation equipment Sterilise feeding equipment Undertake hospital admission, transfer and

discharge on computer system Locating, collecting and filling of hospital records Phoning out and faxing completed discharges Assist in women's nutritional needs- provide refreshments when required Assisting midwives and doctors with preparing equipment and chaperoning procedures Assist in counting swab, instrument and sharps count following procedures Safe disposal or sharps bins Cleaning the birthing pool following the correct procedure Filling the birthing pool to the required temperature
Observed skill & signature, print and date of person you observed
Demonstrated Competence and evidence of education provided.

Undertake vital signs – Temperature Pulse Respiratory rate Blood pressure Oxygen saturations Always document vital signs on a MEOWS chart giving a score and informing the midwife of the results Demonstrate understanding of normal ranges when taking observations Follows plan of care Demonstrates respect of women's privacy and dignity Calculate BMI including taking accurate measurements of height and weight Assist with daily hygiene needs of the women Shower/bath/bed bathing Oral hygiene Obtain specimens of urine and perform urinalysis if requested by midwife or doctor obtain and send mid stream specimen of urine (MSU) correctly Care of woman with indwelling urinary catheter Removal of a Foleys catheter Record oral fluid intake

and fluid output on fluid balance chart Removal of intravenous (IV) cannula Obtain a capillary sample of maternal blood for glucose estimation Apply a TENS machine Recognise signs of ill health and report immediately Obtain and process swabs for microbiology
Observed skill & signature, print and date of person you observed
Demonstrated Competence and evidence of education provided.

Identification and security of baby ( Ensuring x2 name bands insitu) Assessing daily bowel motions and assessment of bowel motion Daily assessment of wet nappies to ensure hydration Weighing of babies accurately Daily care of a baby Eye care Cord care Obtain capillary sample of blood via heel prick for blood glucose Newborn blood spot following midwife discussion with the woman and consent obtained Reinforce current information for general wellbeing and safety of the newborn such as cot death advice Undertake vital signs of a baby Temperature Respiratory rate Heart rate(APEX) Saturations Assess for any breathing difficulties – grunting, nasal flaring and recession Have awareness of the above vital sign values
Infant feeding Showing understanding of the UNICEF baby friendly recommendations
Observed skill & signature, print and date of person you observed
Demonstrated Competence and evidence of education provided.

Attend the breastfeeding friendly training (Mandatory) Be aware of the breastfeeding policy and guidelines Promotes breastfeeding Informs parents about the benefits of breast milk to mother and baby Assist the mother to breastfeed Provide the women with evidence based advice and support Assist with positioning and attachment Assist with hand expression Assist woman with use of breast pump Assist with syringe/cup feeding of expressed breast milk Awareness to only give formula milk on a clinical need basis instructed by midwife or doctor
Observed skill & signature, print and date of person you observed
Demonstrated Competence and evidence of education provided.

Demonstrate baby bathing Top and tailing Assist with mothering skills including nappy changing, dressing baby, holding baby and feeding baby. Promote skin to skin and bonding Help parents understand and read babies cues and behaviours Report to the midwife any concerns/worries about parenting or wellbeing of mother or baby
Observed skill & signature, print and date of person you observed
Demonstrated Competence and evidence of education provided.
Knowledge of emergency contacts Get appropriate help Be present and visible to follow instruction and act as runner Obtain emergency equipment Scribe/ Documentation of events

On instruction and direct supervision assist in lying bed flat and Mc Roberts positioning (Shoulder Dystocia) On instruction and direct supervision assist with placing woman into knee chest position( Cord Prolapse) Assist the Midwife and Doctor in gathering equipment and adjusting the bed as instructed Care of partner and baby during maternal emergencies First aid response to a baby who has breathing difficulties (eg.Chockin)
Skills to achieve by further trust training. On completion of trust training and competence assessed the MCA will be able to give the below care while at Mid Essex Services.
Observed skill shown & signature, print and date of personal observing
Supervised skill demonstrated signature, print and date of supervised skill.
Demonstrated competence and evidence of education provided.

Venepuncture Cannulation Smoking cessation and use of carbon monoxide (CO) monitor Insertion of an indwelling urinary catheter Process umbilical cord and fetal scalp PH Removal of an epidural catheter Nasogastric tube feeding Applying an ECG machine Additional Skills List

data.text: Maternity Care Assistant Skills/Tasks that will Require Further Training
Skills not to be undertaken by  Maternity Care Assistants
Interpretation, decision making and planning of care for the woman and her baby ( Including decisions based upon urinalysis, blood results and blood sugar results)
Provide primary advice and information including telephone advice
Give advice/information on pain relief in pregnancy
Monitor progress of labour including maternal and fetal wellbeing
Assess initial labour or postnatal observations or post operative recovery observations
Supervise student midwives other than demonstrate MCA role under delegation from a midwife
Clearing away other health professionals sharps
Discharge and transfer of care to appropriate professional
Be the 2nd person attending a home birth
Obtain consent for any invasive procedures
Abdominal examination and assessment of uterine activity of a woman
Ausciltation of the fetal heart by hand held or fetal monitor
Giving any medication to mother or baby including drawing up medication, running through an intravenous line, flushing cannula and the checking of any medication.
Holding medicine keys at any time
Wound care including removal or skin stables and sutures
Delivery of a baby , episiotomy or perineal repair
Supra pubic pressure during Shoulder Dystocia
Rubbing up a contraction during a post partum haemorrhage
Totalling fluid balance charts at midnight and working out the positive/negative result

Please note in an extreme emergency the MCA if the only person available may be asked to assist in an emergency procedure under direct instruction and supervision by a midwife. Responsibility and accountability in this situation will remain with the delegating midwife and documentation should reflect this.
Evidence for your personal file of completion of the Green MCA skill requirements (6months from start date, 12 months for Bank staff)
Rotation area on completion: Trust Induction:

A development plan is to focus and track areas of learning and skills you wish to gain. By completing a developmental plan we can clearly see what you want to achieve, this will contribute to your appraisals every year and can be used as evidence.

table_items.text: Objectives: what do I want to be able to do

Implementation: how will I use what I have learnt

File:  09062 Maternity Mandatory Training 6.0 Updated Nov 18  Version:
Author:  Gemma May, Maternity Services, MEHT NHS  Last Reviewed / Next Review Date:June 2014 / June 2017
Bank and Agency Midwives Induction Checklist
Mandatory Training Policy for Maternity Services (Incorporating Training Needs Analysis)/ 09062/ 5.05

table_items.text: Welcome to Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust. We hope you enjoy working here as a Bank/Agency Midwife. All Bank and Agency midwives are to complete two first attender's induction checklist. One will be Maternity specific and the other a Trust requirement. (Please Refer to the Trust Induction Policy No.08079). The Trust first attender's induction form you need to complete for the Bank Office, a copy of this has been included and copies must be returned to the bank office and to the Practice Development Midwife to be entered onto the register at the front of the induction folder in the Bank Office. (Please Refer to the Trust Induction Policy No.08079). The Midwifery specific first attender's checklist must be returned to the Practice Development Midwife to maintain a local register of induction. It is your responsibility to complete this document, and to ensure you have been made aware, and understood all the elements listed below before ticking the column concerned. The form should be used at the beginning of your first shift. This induction pack is a helpful guide to your new work place and a key tool in learning basic information as well useful contacts to make your orientation easier It is not intended to replace policy and procedure folders, which are to be found in the offices of the relevant areas, and on the Trust Intranet. As in most establishments, it is the responsibility of each member of staff to ensure they know where to locate this information.

data.text: Mandatory Training Policy for Maternity Services (Incorporating Training Needs Analysis)/ 09062/ 5.05

table_items.text: Please use chart below to record when you have received an orientation to each new ward/department that you work on as a first attendance. It is your responsibility to complete this document, and to ensure you have been made aware, and understood all the elements listed below before ticking the column concerned. The form should be used at the beginning of your first shift only on a ward/department. Your name will now be entered on the register at the front of the induction folder. For BANK Staff the Office will be notified so that a central record is kept of your first attendance in every area you work. If you are booked for an area the first time, or the BANK Office has no record of your form completion, you will be requested to complete a first attendance form.
Tour of ward, basic ward/department routines, roles & functions of other staff
Occupational Health Service: Needle stick actions
Facilities e.g. toilets, staff rooms etc.
Documentation, location of policies & procedures (especially hand hygiene)

data.text: Mandatory Training Policy for Maternity Services (Incorporating Training Needs Analysis)/ 09062/ 5.05

table_items.text: Agency / Locum / Bank Office / Temporary Staff
One copy to Bank office & one copy to PDM

Awareness to maintain own mandatory training and supervisory reviews annually
Awareness of escalation policy within MEHT (Supervisor and manager of call )
Maternity specific emergency telephone numbers and bleep numbers

data.text: Mandatory Training Policy for Maternity Services (Incorporating Training Needs Analysis)/ 09062/ 5.05

table_items.text: Competence in using fresh eyes within MEHT
Can access trust guidelines and policies (IT/Hard Copy)
Agency / Locum / Bank Office / Temporary Staff
Please keep this for your records and one copy to the PDM

There are two buzzers widely used within maternity one being a general “patient call buzzer” and a louder continuous “emergency buzzer”. Familiarise yourself with these and also the electronic wall mounted panel which indicated what area and bed the buzzer is coming from. It is everyone's responsibility to answer both buzzers and act appropriately within completing this task.
How to use the trust pager system

It is an important tool for all staff to be able to use our pager system when delegated to do so. If possible, stay near the phone until the person has returned your call but please take into consideration that although it only takes less than a minute to activate, the recipient will need to be available and have access to a phone. If the recipient is expected to call back to another extension, please ensure that there is someone available to answer the call.

data.text: Mandatory Training Policy for Maternity Services (Incorporating Training Needs Analysis)/ 09062/ 5.05

table_items.text: If called into a room to assist and the task is delegated to page another member of staff please use phones and resources provided in the room if available. Dial #6555- you will then hear “welcome to the multi-tone paging system” as soon as you hear “welcome” you can enter the required pager number You will then hear “thank you please enter 4 digit message” this is your receiving contact number for the call to be returned to. Your message will then be processed and you can hang up and await message

In emergencies you might be asked to put one of two rapid emergency calls out this is completed by dialling ‘4444' from any phone. This will go straight to switch, whom will instantly call all appropriate people according to the code you give. The two codes we use are:
Code Blue – This is related to the baby
Code Red – This is related to the mother
With each call give the code and location of the incident.

data.text: Mandatory Training Policy for Maternity Services (Incorporating Training Needs Analysis)/ 09062/ 5.05

table_items.text: 09:00 - 21:00 Anyone welcome - but only 3 per bed and no under 16's allowed 15:00 - 16:00 19:00 - 20:00
Staff may only park in the designated staff parking areas by displaying a valid parking permit. To obtain or renew your permit contact the car parking office on ext 6115.

You will be given a password to access the PAS system once you have received training from a designated person. You will need to contact Lynne Lambert, Ward Clerk, on extension 3057, Labour Ward for training.

Computers are available for staff to use in all clinical areas. To gain access contact IT after sending your IT form after Trust induction. Email accounts can be accessed on any computer (MEHT Account only). It is to your benefit that you obtain e-mail access as soon as possible as most information is disseminated in this way, such as newsletters, new guidelines etc. You will need to contact the IT Department to set up your account on 5000.

data.text: Mandatory Training Policy for Maternity Services (Incorporating Training Needs Analysis)/ 09062/ 5.05

table_items.text: In line with national standards, the units are covered by a CCTV system. All staff are issued with a photo ID swipe card which MUST be worn at ALL times. A copy of all security guidelines are kept on each ward. There are lockers available in the clinical areas for use while on duty. It is advisable not to bring unnecessary valuables on to the site.
There is a strict infection prevention policy across the Trust. A copy of the policy is available on the Trust Intranet

Appropriate behaviour is required at all times in line with Trust guidelines. Rudeness is always unacceptable and a caring supportive atmosphere between staff is essential. We have a strict uniform policy at this Trust and a copy of this can be found in every clinical area and also on the Trust intranet.

data.text: Mandatory Training Policy for Maternity Services (Incorporating Training Needs Analysis)/ 09062/ 5.05

table_items.text: Please note theatre blues should only be worn in theatre and on Labour Ward. No mobile phones or any other personal electronic items are permitted on the clinical area unless during your designated break.

Any concerns with mandatory training or training needs within MEHT Maternity Services, please contact the Practice Development Midwife for advice Gemma May - T: 01245 513080 | E: Gemma.May@meht.nhs.uk

Please note it is your responsibility to ensure your mandatory training is valid maintained up to date Mandatory fields include: Safeguarding up to level 3 CTG Skills and Drills Manual handling Record keeping Blood Competencies Equipment As a Bank/Agency only midwife it is also your responsibility to arrange your annual own supervisory review with your Supervisor of Midwives within your local area.
All blood tests are analysed at Broomfield, samples sent via

data.text: Mandatory Training Policy for Maternity Services (Incorporating Training Needs Analysis)/ 09062/ 5.05

table_items.text: specimen Shute in each area X-rays and ultrasound scans are available at Broomfield. There is the PATH computer system for obtaining blood results; you will be given training and a password if a regular bank/agency midwife with us for obtaining these results. IT Helpdesk can be contacted on ex 5000 All samples and request forms should be inserted in a designated clear plastic bag and then placed in the transport canisters. Out of hours blood samples – contact Biochemistry ext 4159/4162 to inform them that you are sending a sample via the specimen Shute. Listed below are the most common blood tests that are carried out in the maternity unit:
Blue top X-match, group, antibody screen,
Brown top U & E, LFT's uric acid
